intro: Iguanura geonomiformis subvar. ramosa, commonly known as the hairy sycamore, is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family and is native to tropical regions of South America. It is characterized by its large, palmately lobed leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, which are followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Due to its unique morphology and ecological role, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
